awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Tailoring Terahertz Emission in Ultrafast Multi-Functional Devices using Reduced-Dimensional Hybrid Metal Perovskites
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical: 
Terahertz technologies hold great promise for future computing and communications. Energy-efficient and miniaturized THz sources using light-weight, low-cost, and robust materials are a long sought goal. Few materials, however, possess the attributes needed to realize working devices. Metal halide perovskites with reduced dimensionality are a new class of semiconductors with great promise for such applications. They can be inexpensively synthesized and solution processed, have attractive electronic properties, and tolerate defects. These properties have led to great interest for applications in solar cells and flexible displays. Perovskites also show promise as high performance THz sources. Remarkably, these properties can be controlled via spin electronics (spintronics) that exploit the fundamental properties of electrons in devices. This makes it possible to interface perovskites with magnetic materials, enabling spintronic THz emitters. This project will lead to low-cost and energy-efficient THz devices with complementary magnetic, optical and electronic functions. The PIs will educate graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, by integrating research with education. Established and developing outreach programs will be used to involve K-12 students with the project.

Technical:
This project focuses on the realization of a spintronic control of the broadband THz emission in RD-HMH/Ferromagnet heterostructures. The research consists of three research thrusts: (1) Demonstrate the proof-of-concept spintronic hybrid THz emitter using reduced dimensional-hybrid metal halide (RD-HMH) polycrystalline thin films prepared by a low-cost spin-coating approach, taking advantage of the fast relaxation of spin (akin to a switch) and efficient spin-to-charge interconversion thanks to the heavy metal elements in RD-HMHs. A thorough, fundamental physical understanding of the ultrafast generation of THz emission in RD-HMH/Ferromagnet heterostructures will be unraveled. (2) Tailor the THz emission via engineering RD-HMH single crystals. Wafer-scale single crystals-based THz emitters will be designed and optimized with tunable bandwidth as well as high quality (Q-) factors, in complement to that of polycrystalline-film emitters. (3) Optimize the THz emission via versatile chemical synthetic routes using device building blocks. The available pool of high-quality synthesized RD-HMH candidates with tunable quantum-well effects are ready to be fabricated into efficient THz emitters, allowing the spintronic and magnetic control of THz generation that can be potentially used for logic applications utilizing THz-wave emission and absorption.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Goals

This project focuses on the realization of a spintronic control of the broadband THz emission in reduced-dimensional hybrid metal halide (RD-HMH)/ferromagnet (FM) heterostructures including demonstrating Proof-of-concept spintronic hybrid THz emitter using RD-HMH/FM heterostructures, tailoring the THz emission via engineering RD-HMH single crystals and arrays, and tailoring the THz emission via versatile chemical synthetic routes of device building blocks.

Intellectual Merit

Specifically, through this Award (three years total), we have achieved the following (not exhaustive, only the highlights):

1)      A total of 8 publications have been published including one in Nature Communications.

2)      Fabricate the first proof-of-concept hybrid spintronic THz emitters using RD-HMH/FM heterostructure; demonstrate the spintronic coherent control of THz emission in 2D-HMH/FM heterostructures; perform key control experiments to verify the observation of THz emissions; and derive theoretical models about the fundamental understanding of asymmetric THz radiation driven by the Rashba state in the RD-HMHs.

3)      Separate the interface- and bulk-dominated spin-to-charge conversions in solution-processed HMH thin films by varying the HMH thin film thickness and interface engineering.

4)      Study the spin-to-charge conversion in HMH single crystals, where the surface Rashba splitting state in a crystal can be directly determined by measuring the spin relaxation time via oblique Hanle precession measurement.

5)      Employ high-throughput materials screening for exploring HMH material space for high THz device performance in the term of the spin-orbit coupling strength that is proportional to the efficiency of spin-to-charge conversion, and the large spin injection efficiency due to the spin filtering effect caused by the bandgap alignment at the interface between FM and HMH.

6)      Elucidate the mechanism of spin-to-charge conversion in organic-based hybrid materials in the absence of heavy metal elements, where the tailored spin-orbit coupling in organic-based polymer system can be directly achieved by tuning the torsion angle of polymer backbones.

7)      Demonstrate a new route of engineering high-performance spintronic THz emitters utilizing doped wide bandgap semiconductors with electrical field tunability.

8)      Explore THz device engineering toward high-performance spintronic THz emitters using ultrawide bandgap inorganic semiconductors and two-dimensional electron gas formed at the Nitride-based semiconductors.

 

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts have been significant, including the following.

1. Research results: Our work in RD-HMH-based spintronic THz emitter will show the realization of ultrafast spin-to-charge conversion in HMH thin-film with THz frequencies. It offers new routes towards interconversion between photons, charges, and spin states using scalable, printable, solution-processed hybrid compounds. The phase and intensity of THz radiation in 2D-HMH materials can be manipulated by the magnetization state of the adjacent ferromagnet and the pump polarization, offering contactless coherent control of the THz radiation utilizing spintronic toolkits.

As for the ultrawide bandgap (UWBG) semiconductor-based spintronic THz emitters, it can be immediately integrated into conventional high-power electronic platforms and also optical platforms as active components of photonic circuits. These UWBG-based spintronic THz emitters would greatly improve the functionality of RF electronic devices by not only reaching the high frequencies that are not achievable via conventional approaches but also enables significant flexibility that is compatible with the current Si- and III-Nitride based semiconductor-manufacturing platform

2. Education and training: This project has been a great opportunity to train graduate students and undergraduate students, all of whom are directly mentored by all the PIs. Training opportunities for research personnel include developing innovative problem solving, data analysis, and data interpretation skills; this work provides the opportunity to develop collaborative skills, and expertise that cross-cuts multiple disciplines. The graduate and undergraduate students were provided numerous opportunities to practice for speaking and presentation skills in both formal and informal settings. Regular informal research presentations are given at laboratory group meetings and at research meetings (total 17 formal conference talks and 14 invited talks) involving all project personnel.

 

3. Publication and presentation: Results obtained in this work have been published in peer reviewed journals (8 publications as of now), and the participants (graduate/undergraduate students and all the PIs) have given research presentations in various venues.

 

4. Outreach to general public, and K-12: Education activities for high school students have been implemented into the current STEM and outreach platforms. The team has been actively participating in a developed outreach platform at NCSU (i.e., ?Launch your Excellent Adventures with Physics! (LEAP!)?) for middle/high school girls during the duration of funding period.

The PI was selected as the Event Supervisor in 2019-2020 NCSO for the ?Simple Machines? event for the state- and national-wide competition. The PI has provided lectures to other coaches through the annual ?NCSO Coaches Clinic? event that serves 450 STEM teachers across the state.
